body: XVI. Laying a Ghost: The Jeannette and the FramAnd melt the spirit; his mouth will distendBeneath the snowflakes I notice façadesTraces of those deep cuts lie thickly uponAway, my songs, must we goFigures of light and dark, these two are walkingAway from their profundity of surface.the foul pole relaxes. She's raged all afternoonI draw near to one of them, the lowest,Silent patch of ultimate paint. You areWould their world not remain comfortablyTo watch me watch drowned snow lift from the lake.He terrifies the Vast, he seems so wild;wonders if she'd ever be brave enoughUnreadable from behindthey are well downThe flakes which have stolen onto the flagstonesCentimetersthat the height of the canvasHoarfrost is in his bones and on his head,Standing in the way of the truth. A white
